threads.com:
We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502953
Citrus and banana wont survive winter.

I would look into plum-apricot hybrids (pluots). If you are partial to japanese plums you will absolutely lose your shit for pluots and pluerries (plum-cherry hybrid). Look for the best pluots in your zone. If Flavor King is on that list plant two. Its that good. Imagine the best possible plum sweetness, no tart skin, with a hint of tropical fruit/banana flavor. If you can grow flavor grenade its a must. The flavor is much more mild than flavor king but its more productive, it has a long season, it hangs on the tree well. It remains crunchy even when ripe and its mostly green/yellow so birds dont bother them as much as other pluots.

For Figs make sure you get common fig and not smyrna if you dont have fig wasp in your area.

Dont plant mulberries neat concrete or structures they stain. Morus Nigra are supposedly the best tasting mulberries.

Persimmon choose between astringent vs non astringent. I personally prefer fuyu over hachiya. Astringents have to be soft before being eaten, think water balloon soft.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2504878
T8 nfs is eva. Same material for tennis shoes that will flatten at about 500 miles and lose cushion. It weighs less though
T8 bifida is polyurethane. Will last a lot longer for cushion but weighs more. More hiking boots use this.
Both subject to hydrolysis .
Both slippery under wet condition but imagine nfs will work better. Ive had slick pu boots.
Military boots tend to not be very water resistant but dry quickly compared to hiking boots. Ive had some success using waterproof socks inside them though. Just be ready to size up.
You can always fix uncomfortable boots with superfeet or my preference of half insoles/cork.
I prefer mini mils but bellevilles lacing system sucks.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503525
>Is there any danger in being so close to the antennas?
The 2way/LMR stuff isn't too bad. 100 watts or so with a couple dB antenna gain on it. Unless you're really close to it or working on the specific antenna when it's still lit up, there's not much of an exposure hazard. Those duty-cycle too, they're only on when someone's using the talk path, so overall exposure is reduced because of the time factor.
Dishes or directional antennas focus that energy in one direction; while they usually have less power into them, all that power is directed one way. Don't stand or work in front of those.
Broadcast transmitters are the scary ones. Lots of power, 100% duty cycle, and they're usually in bands that the body absorbs easily.
The tower in >picrel is AM broadcast, the tower structure is the antenna and it's electrically hot. Knocked power down while we were on it, less for exposure and more to minimize the risk of RF burns in case of accidental contact with the grounded cables I was installing. See https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b9UO9tn4MpI
On top of that tower was a 10-element FM broadcast array with about 50kW out of it.
When I climbed up to set an anchor the day before the install, knowing the two of us were only going to be up there for a short time, we didn't mess with the FM power levels. My alarm got real alarmy up there because of that exposure. The next day during the install, I coordinated with station engineer to ramp down power on that transmitter to acceptable levels while I was working ~15ft below that array.

Part of my pre-climb safety assessment includes RF exposure considerations.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
There are a few waterproofing fabric solutions
For USGI (and most other ponchos,) they use polyurethane-coated polyester, which gives it that signature rubbery feel on the outside. Having used one for 2 weeks in Mississippi during the summer, honestly it's not that bad, if extremely cumbersome to don and doff. If you're in a rainy area you can't go wrong with a poncho.
There are other, more hiker-oriented fabrics, including GORE-TEX, DWR coating, Silnylon shells and Silpoly shells.
If you drive a Tesla to National Park trails, you should consider GORE
Everyone else should consider how much rain they're gonna be facing.
>Light misting? DWR is great for that
>Intermittent rain? Silnylon and most popular rain jackets will work but they wet out
>Heavy rain that comes down like a bitch? Definitely silpoly
Silpoly sure as shit makes you sweaty, but pit zips help offset that a lot. Honestly I'd prefer being a little sweaty over having shitty rain gear that wets out and becomes useless over time

Really there's no "wrong" rain gear, it's just what you prefer. I'd prefer just the basics instead of chinesium dead bird bullshit

Good week for mushrooms ahead edition

>Community-based tools for IDing and Cataloguing
Mushroomobserver.org
The Bolete Filter: https://boletes.wpamushroomclub.org/
Inaturalist app (directly draws data from mushroomobserver but is itself a more generalized platform)
Google Scholar: Massive resource for papers and studies regarding current clinical and indigenous uses of medicinal fungi.

If you expect to get a remotely meaningful ID here, you need to be taking photos of the mushroom as you found it, on it's substrate, a clear shot of the top and side view of it, and a clear shot of the gills/pores/stipe/stem or otherwise the entire undercarriage of the mushroom. every detail of the encounter helps, where, when, what was the weather, etc.
If you want people who do this for a living to give their guess on ID's, take all of the above and make quality observations on Mushroomobserver.

This science needs as much redundant ID and loacation data as possible, any observation has value and is a meaningful contribution that takes a few more seconds than just taking a picture of the pretty thing you saw in the woods.

last_replies.com:
>>2503889
There are many different accessories that can be helpful when fishing from a kayak, depending on your specific needs and preferences. Some common accessories that many kayak fishermen like to have include:

A fishing rod holder to keep your rod secure while you paddle or fish.

A fish finder to help you locate fish and other underwater structures.

A bait bucket or cooler to keep your bait fresh and store your catch.

A paddle leash to prevent your paddle from floating away if you drop it.

A dry bag to protect your belongings from water and keep them dry.

A waterproof map case to keep your maps and other important documents safe from water.

A kayak anchor to help you stay in one spot while fishing.

A waterproof flashlight or headlamp for fishing at night or in low-light conditions.

A landing net to help you safely bring your catch aboard your kayak.

A kayak cart to make it easier to transport your kayak to and from the water.

It is also important to have all necessary safety gear, such as a personal flotation device (PFD) and a whistle or other signaling device. Make sure to check local regulations for any other required gear or permits.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Welcome to my blog. I did a 1200 mile thru hike this summer and was underprepared in many ways. About 600 miles in I woke up late one day in the Pasayten Wilderness and aimed for about 25 miles. Coming up to Cathedral Pass the rain clouds that had been dogging me all day suddenly landed right on top of me. I could see Cathedral in the distance getting pelted with sheets of rain. Realized I might die and was overjoyed at this prospect so I kept walking. It was rain at first, then hail and sleet, then snow. 3 inches of water flowing down the trail. No flat ground to speak of. Ball lightning striking the peaks above me. My pack was lined in a contractor bag. My rain layer wet out in a matter of minutes. Started shaking so violently I couldn’t walk a straight line anymore. I told myself I’d stop as soon as I found a spot to set the tent out. Found a patch of somewhat level ground and managed to set my tent up in the rain while shaking violently with blue fingers. Climbed inside, stripped everything off, climbed into my dry 20 degree quilt. Shook violently and contemplated death for about an hour and half while reading an ebook on my phone. It stopped raining so I put my dry clothes on and walked another 5 miles. Now I always carry an emergency blanket and preemptively take shelter to avoid rain if possible. Cold and wet is a death sentence

Geeks/weirdos naturally left (or felt forced out) before high school. The troop's "established" families with tiger-dads ran the show, whether or not they still wore their little uniforms. I've met some relatively well-adjusted Scouting devotees but the existence of the club/cult seems like a symptom of a deeper problem. If you had a nice experience, OK, but I hope you're prepared to pass it on to the next generation without the BSA's artificial trappings.

Plug it into the charger in the truck on the drive home, 2 hours later it's blinking green, half hour after that it's solid/full-charged.
So basically the solar charger didn't do a fucking thing but turn the red LED on.

For the size and weight of the charger/solar panels, I can carry a lot of charged batteries.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2496241
"Van Life" is best enjoyed if you have some reason to travel in order to make that way of living worthwhile. The convenience of living rent/motel free means that a 3 month trip becomes a lot more achievable to those with only a couple grand savings.

Driving a van is a bit of a PITA and you will want to do short hops from town to town and do a bit of exploring, then rest up overnight and go another 30mins/hour down the road and explore that place, or do whatever.
Great if you're travelling to rock climb every major spot in the country, or surf every good beach, go to every national park or go to every Six Flags ect. You kind of need a directive to make the most of it.

As a permanent way of living it is one step departed from living in a motel or a tent.
If you are intending on doing it for a cheap existence and not a holiday then go find a homeless community like Slab City and live there in your van because that's the true permanent living solution. You won't run into any issues with squatting there.

If you have a job, rent a place because the benefits far outweigh the money you save living inside a 3x2meter box.

I never said it's the most versatile instrument. What I said is that it's a lot of bang for the buck (where the currency is size - the smaller the better). You get two full octaves of a major scale, with (a useful) bit of a third on the bottom. You get a minor scale and all the modes in between. There's hundreds of tunes you can play with just this. And there's lots of room for expression: wide dynamic range, chords (limited, but they're there, and they are useful in typical for-harmonica tunes), bends. Name a different literally pocket sized instrument that's this versatile.

Hello Out

I want to go on a long and extended walk/hike/trek in Scotland where wild camping is legal so I can relax for an extended period of time without slipping into decadence like people do at holiday resorts and have nothing to do but walk and read. I plan to do this summer 2023 after my A levels and before university. By then I will have at least £1000 in savings and probably more (I now have about £900). Will this be feasible.

£1.70 for a weeks worth of rice
£0.60 for a weeks worth of carrots
£5 for two lamb chops
£3 for a roll of proper bread (normal supermarket bread in the uk is actually a bread substitute but if you’re willing to pay extra you can get actual bread quite easily).

I should note that I’m an autist so I won’t mind eating mostly rice with other food in smaller amounts to get necessary nutrients and would probably prefer it over variation as I like routine.

I imagine I could roast vegetables easily in a mess tin (German/polish/Russian variety) and make a decent if oddly shaped Yorkshire pudding in the removable dish that comes with the mess kit.

Shelter: bothies. Carry a zeltbhan in case I can’t find a bothy.

Entertainment: the natural world+books. I will buy books to read on the trip and then pass them on or something when I’m done with them.

Clothes:
I’ll bring 2 pairs of trousers and 3/4 cotton or linen shirts. I’ll also bring a jumper or two. Will be packed in a rucksack.

I also want to do this to prove to my friends that cost of living is low outside of rent and vices
but that is an afterthought that came to me whilst typing this post. My main motivation is a sense of wanderlust and desire for solitude to think and to read.

Misc:
Needles+thread
Lighter
Swiss army knife
Water bottle
Might bring an axe
Torch

Anything I’ve missed? Is this feasible?

get good underwear that are also go down to your knees, skin shafing is worse on longer walks, preferably in material that both breaths and dries, because non-dry material causes even more shafing. experiment with different layers of socks and try them all out for at least 10km and see if you get blisters or not, and get used with your shoes. if you ever feel sore or numb in your feet or legs, take a LONG rest, atleast an hour if not more, because the recovery sucks when your out in the middle of nowhere; i was an idiot when i first started out, didn't take rests and ended up with two stress fractures, pain and misery for a month

and lose weight if you haven't, unless it's like carrying several backpacks

threads.sub: Why do people like kukris so much?
threads.com: I bought myself a kukri a year or so ago, used it extensively as a camp duty tool. It really seems like a neat idea in theory but in practice it just doesn't work for me no matter how hard I try. It's too cumbersome to be a good replacement for a knife, it's too light to be a good replacement for a hatchet. It's also a pain in the ass to take care of due to the fact that it has a recurve shape. The only scenario where it's actually reasonable to use it is clearing slightly thick branches or really thick weeds where a regular machete doesn't have enough weight to cut through. I can't count how many times I found myself wishing I packed proper tools instead. Why are people so obsessed about these things? Have I fallen for a meme?

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Beginner Gear General - Poor Fag Edition
threads.com:
I wanted to make a thread for General new gear and where to get it. Also for Larpers and Woodsman alike to avoid the pit falls I fell into when choosing gear for the first time over 2 years ago. i'll try to aim for a good gear loadout under 200$. Also any criticisms or better options should be talked about here.

Ill first go by stating the things no anon should ever cheap out on.
>boots
you should aim for boots over 200$ price range eventually, but if you are just getting started buy military surplus boots. But If you can avoid do not buy the recent desert tan army boots that run 20$. They have very thick soles and no ankle support , its a good way to give yourself a sprang ankle, they are also not very breathable or water proof. But I used them for a year so they are workable but do have a week or 2 brake in period.

Next is backpacks I see many on here choose a military surplus backpack, My experience with a US military molle 2 rucksack is that its usable at best but too heavy. Military sacrifices price and quality material for an indestructible pack that an idiot can't destroy. You are better off with a used frame backpack or internal backpack.

I have found that most milltary backpacks are around 65-120$ a used backpacking bag is around 20$ on shopgoodwill.com. I hear you say that you don't want to stand out in the woods , I would say their are plenty of waterproof rain flys for your bag that come in non-IRreflective camo for 45$ or a Chinese rain fly for 10$ on amazon, which are better than what ever camo you were thinking about buying any how. A good capacity is 65 liters, this is considered 3 day bag but if your smart you can fit rations for a full week in it. 55 liters is fine but the limit for fitting a sleeping bag and not limiting the gear you might want to take. Finally you need to have a waist support for your backpack as well as a frame , this should go without saying a duffel bag is a pain to hull around 5 miles.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Hell yeah. One of the most fun part of motorcycling is the ease of camping. This is me after firing the bike into a park that was closed for the season via the pedestrian footpath, and I decided to bring luxury as I was staying for 3 days and brought a tent. Normally, I sleep under my cover - I bought a dark green ATV cover for the cruiser, as it has enough space underneath it to cover the bike fully while also allowing me to ground sleep underneath it. This time, I wanted some comforts, and turns out a 6 man tent will fit a decent wheelbase machine nicely. Did a few wrapped in a greatcoat under that cover while the night temperature hut freezing, which was amusing waking up with frost on the cover to then go riding down the same roads. I always have that green cover and a flat-packable woodstove in my saddlebag, just in case I feel like getting silly. Dirtbag camping is a riot!

Anon if you have a PhD in engineering and you can't afford to ski then you either aren't making anywhere near what you could or you have terrible money management. IDK what to tell you, but ski mountains are quite busy.

Budget for a ski season:
Boots: = $500/5 seasons = $100
Skis is same (buy used), so another $100
Poles = $50/5 = $10
Jacket, $200/5 = $40
Pants, $200/5 = $40
socks, helmet, other personal items: $300/5 = $60
Season pass: $800 (your mileage may vary)
Assuming you drive 90 miles to go to the resort and gas is $3.50 and your rig gets 30 MPG: $10.50 * 2 (because both directions) * 20 days/season = $420

Total: $1570/season. Sorry you're poor anon, but frankly if you can't come up with $1570 dollars for a ski season then that's your problem.

Not really.
Nylon degrades over time. How it's stored also affects that material (hot car, near chemicals/cleaners if you keep it in the garage).
